text:
<@UCGAK10LS> (et al) — As far as current rules and guidelines go, this sort of discussion is fine for <#C01932BJGE8|present-company> as long as everyone keeps their cool. I find it interesting, but I'm opting to not participate because my political views are incendiary (or at least I like to think they are, haha). As a non-American, I'm with you that it would be nice to see more discussion of non-American politics, especially as it pertains to FoC (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_Cybersyn|Project Cybersyn> comes to mind). But I view that as an "in addition to", not an "instead of" this sort of discussion.

It's good that you voiced your concern about the discussion. I'll take all the feedback I can get — just because I feel "fine" with it doesn't mean it's good for the health of the community. If you'd like to talk about it more, send me a DM or feel free to spin up a new discussion in <#CEXED56UR|administrivia>.

text: I do object a bit here <@UC2A2ARPT>. I do understand that the matter has some relations with present ongoing election and political scene in America but I also firmly believe that it represents a side of technology that we should all be very cautious about. This is a powerhouse of bad things and Future of Coding does not only mean Technological or Design advances in computer science but it also means ethically better computing. Don't you agree? I am a non-american and I posted this here for that reason. Not to discuss or ignite a discussion about American politics rather to discuss what FoC can do to prevent such kind of sources.

I am a non-american and I posted this here for that reason. Not to discuss or ignite a discussion about American politics rather to discuss what FoC can do to prevent such kind of sources.

text:
<@UPVBV34EL>

Let's split this into a few pieces.

• The American vs non stuff is mostly in reference to Kartik's first post and Nick's post, not the rest of the thread.
• The question of relevance to FoC is mostly a matter of framing. We could have an FoC-oriented discussion on the subject (or, really, any subject). But you began this thread with "Not directly FoC but I guess highly important", which isn't much of a prompt for any particular kind of discussion. If you'd like to point the conversation in a new direction, by all means go for it. Tell us a little more of what you think about the ideas in article.

text:
<@UPVBV34EL> It's not clear to me what you're objecting to. You seem in agreement with Ivan.

I really like this arrangement where we can discuss all aspects of the present as we focus on a single aspect of the future.

text:
> single aspect of the future
Pretty sure aspect-oriented programming deserves its place in the dustbin of history.

_ba-dum tsch_ :ivan:

elements.text: Pretty sure aspect-oriented programming deserves its place in the dustbin of history.

text: I agree on that <@UC2A2ARPT> that my original post wordings were poorly chosen. And I probably should have written something about how I feel this is a growing problem for the time to come. I grew up in an Analog First world in India in 1990's and the more the world is becoming digital first the more strange problem are arising which we are very poorly equipped to solve at the moment. I sometimes feel that often we do not understand the true implications of a particular innovation in its full breadth and depth.
